data.title: bean, n.Â¹ â€” Greenâ€™s Dictionary of Slang
data.text:
bean n.1

1. as units of money.

(a) money, irrespective of the coin (cf. beans n.1 ).

W. Cartwright Ordinary V iv: I do not reche / One bean for all. Wkly Rake (NY) 30 July n.p.: wants to knowWhether Moll S. did that thing with the â€˜countrymanâ€™ just for beans, as she said. Sam Sly 2 June 4/3: Though very poor she wished to show, / That her dear daughter had a bean; / And ordered lots of flashy dress, / Which doubtless cost five pounds. Letters by an Odd Boy 160: Beans, blunt, brass, bustle, coppers, chinkers, chips, dibbs, mopusses, needful, ochre, pewter, quids, rays, rowdy, shiners, stuff, tin, and stumpy! E. Townsend Chimmie Fadden Explains 93: I never put up a bean; never showed de color of de long green onct. Truth (Sydney) 17 Mar. 7/7: Stamper was bound to be quiet because he was not supposed to have lost a bean. Binstead & Wells Pink â€™Un and Pelican 248: The millionaires go out among the hoboes that havenâ€™t got a bean, and there ensues a brief era of couters and good feeling. Bulletin (Sydney) 19 May 11/3: Let never a â€˜beanâ€™ by you be missed, / Youâ€™re told, you know, you must insist! W. Irwin Confessions of a Con Man 45: I landed there without a bean. Sport (Adelaide) 19 July 9/3: They Say [...] That When Snorkey started [...] he never had a bean. â€˜Sapperâ€™ Mufti 159: Charming without a bean in the world isnâ€™t a fact â€” itâ€™s a farce. Van Vechten Nigger Heaven 37: You see, I havenâ€™t a bean. D. Footman Pig and Pepper (1990) 207: Damn it, old man, when I arrived here three months ago without a bean [...] you backed me up. H. Drake-Brockman â€˜Priceâ€™ in Mann Coast to Coast 48: Itâ€™d been right enough at first, quite all right that every bean should go back into the land. K. Amis letter 16 Jan. in Leader (2000) 195: The time to worry about money is when you havenâ€™t a bean to bless yourself with. R. Chandler Long Good-Bye 15: The guy was down and out, starving, dirty, without a bean. F. Norman Dead Butler Caper 75: My husband died and left me without a bean. F. Taylor Auf Wiedersehen Pet Two 154: They might just repossess the houses and kick you all out without a bean. J. Baker Walking With Ghosts (2000) 167: Gambles everything heâ€™s got. Comes away from the table without a bean. Sun. Times News Rev. 12 Mar. 1: After a lifetime of stocks, shares, contacts and commissions, the rich man hasnâ€™t a bean.

(b) a sovereign, a guinea.

Lex. Balatronicum n.p.: Bean. A guinea. Half bean; half a guinea. â€˜Jon Beeâ€™ Dict. of the Turf, the Ring, the Chase, etc. H. Smith Gale Middleton 1 148: â€˜Whatâ€™s the swag?â€™ â€˜Not much; only two beans and a bullâ€™. Hotten Dict. of Modern Sl. etc. 4: Formerly bean meant a guinea. â€˜Scene in a London Flash-Pannyâ€™ Matsell Vocabulum 99: It was no great quids, Jimâ€”only six flimseys and three beans. C. Reade Hard Cash II 246: What me fake the beans, now I live this side of the fence? Sl. Dict. D.C. Murray Rainbow Gold III 140: â€˜Hereâ€™s some of the beans,â€™ he continued figuratively, as he drew five sovereigns from the same pocket. â€˜Prince Albertâ€™s Fashionâ€™ at warrenfahey.com ğŸŒ Anâ€™ runs accounts for underwear / Anâ€™ banks their beans anâ€™ rocks. J. Ware Passing Eng. of the Victorian Era. Western Mail (Perth) 28 May 21/1: [from Daily Mail, London] A sovereign had a lot of slang names [...] a portrait, a yellow boy, [...] a foont, a poona [and] a bean. G. Seal Lingo 36: A bean is a guinea or money in general, retaining this meaning in the phrase without a bean.

(c) a $5 gold piece.

Trumble Sl. Dict. (1890) 8: Bean. A five dollar gold piece].

(d) (also beano, green bean) a dollar.

T.A. Dorgan in Zwilling TAD Lex. (1993) 16: Why the old turk wouldnâ€™t have had a bean if I let half the creditors in. L. Chevalier â€˜Getting into Societyâ€™ Variety Stage Eng. Plays ğŸŒ I cough up ten beans to hear Caruso strangle â€˜The Bohemian Girlâ€™! Ade Hand-made Fables 84: He allows that he will shoot every Bean in the old Tin Box and die Poor. C.B. Booth â€˜Mr Clacksworthy Within the Lawâ€™ Detective Story 13 Aug. ğŸŒ Mrs. Bascom vamped old money-bags outta them fifty thousand beanos. M. Prenner â€˜Sl. Terms for Moneyâ€™ in AS IV:5 358: â€˜Dollar,â€™ of course, is well represented. It is a bean, berry, bone, buck. M. Fulcher â€˜Believe Meâ€™ in Afro-American (Baltimore, MD) 16 Feb. 12/3: [T]wo beans / Is the sum total of wealth in my jeans. J. Lilienthal Horse Crazy 11: Without a coat on his back or a bean in his pocket [W&F]. (con. 1948) G. Mandel Flee the Angry Strangers 257: I want four hundred beans. [Ibid.] 384: They wanna give away a billion and a half green beans. H. Ellison â€˜High Diceâ€™ in Gentleman Junkie 87: He was into me for about seventy beans. (con. 1930sâ€“50s) D. Wells Night People 117: Beans. Dollars. R. De Christoforo Grease 86: They must be worth two beans apiece, easy. Kool G Rao â€˜Road to the Richesâ€™ ğŸµ There were four kinda fiends bringin jackets and jeans / Magazines, anything, just to hustle a bean. L. Tsai â€˜Shooting Poolâ€™ in Anthologist Fall ğŸŒ The tall guyâ€™s saying something to me about money. Fifty beans? I just smile and nod. J. Hawkins in Golf Digest July ğŸŒ Tour policy requires each player to leave a minimum tip of $20 per tournament, which isnâ€™t to be confused with the going rate for golfâ€™s upper class: Fifty beans if you miss the cut, $100 if you play all four days.

(e) (US) a dollar bill â€“ any denomination.

E. Townsend Chimmie Fadden and Mr Paul 75: How about de fiver? [...] De long, crisp, clean, green bean I give you?

(f) a small or derisory amount of money.

T.I. Rubin Sweet Daddy 56: They get beans for a check. Christ they must be nuts. [Ibid.] 114: The chick gets beans, peanuts. T.C. Bambara â€˜Playing with Punjabâ€™ in Gorilla, My Love (1972) 70: I got this boss place [...] for four beans you can move right in and everythingâ€™s yours.

(g) a poker chip.

Wentworth & Flexner DAS.

2. (Aus.) the epitome of fashion.

Bellâ€™s Life in Sydney 10 Oct. 4/1: Must I allow my old Nugee [i.e. a coat made by that London tailor] / That made me once the beanâ€”the thing / Exposed in a Jewâ€™s shop to be / Or at his dirty door to swing.

3. the genitals.

(a) the penis.

Trimble 5000 Adult Sex Words and Phrases. Maledicta IV:2 (Winter) 192: Elision also occurs with bean, which is short for beanstalk or beanpole.

(b) (US) the hymen; thus cop a bean, to deflower, to have sexual intercourse.

Goldin et al. DAUL 24/2: Bean. (Irish-American, especially in New York State) The hymen. â€˜To cop a beanâ€™ â€“ To have sexual intercourse with a virgin.

(c) the clitoris; in combs.; see bean flicker ; flick the bean

implied at bean flicker

4. (also beanie, beano) the head.

H. Green Maison De Shine 130: Pop swung on a guy anâ€™ come near knockinâ€™ his bean offa him. R. Lardner You Know Me Al (1984) 143: I forgot all about the ball game and I cut loose at his bean. Day Book (Chicago) 18 Nov. 14/2: Thatâ€™s another one knocked out. I surely busted Willie on the beanie. N. Putnam West Broadway 98: You can begin, if you let your bean work, to get some notion of the breadth of our civilization. Wodehouse Inimitable Jeeves 85: Youâ€™ve just finished exercising the old bean. D. Hammett â€˜The Big Knockoverâ€™ Story Omnibus (1966) 300: He had to make a show of it when he should have ben using his bean. D. Runyon â€˜Breach of Promiseâ€™ Runyon on Broadway (1954) 28: This [...] causes her to slug Mr. Jabez Tuesday on the bean. H. Miller Tropic of Capricorn (1964) 247: Plato had an idea or two in his bean, yes sir, yes siree. D. Burley N.Y. Amsterdam Star-News 17 Oct. 10: Perfect rums who knock themselves out with a lot of rugcutting [...] while the beam is beaming and the town is dreaming. Wodehouse Mating Season 28: As if a bomb had suddenly exploded inside the bean. Wodehouse Jeeves and the Feudal Spirit 4: Her bean crammed to bursting point with the little grey cells. B. Appel Tough Guy [ebook] â€˜How about usinâ€™ the old bean? [...] The guy whoâ€™s tough ainâ€™t in the same class as the guy whoâ€™s tough and smartâ€™. T.I. Rubin In the Life 111: Oh screw it, Doc. A little thing pops into my bean and you make a big spread about it. T. Wolfe Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test (1969) 19: I have been through some crewcut college fraternity weekends that have been weirder-looking and -sounding, insane on the beano. L. Rosten Dear â€˜Hermâ€™ 15: I thought about our old class some more â€“ and the name of â€˜Shemlyâ€™ Botnick invaded the old bean! [Ibid.] 150: Flo is no dum-dum. She has eyes in back of her beano. J. Wambaugh Glitter Dome (1982) 42: The unyielding brass bean of the chubby Chinese deity. S. Morgan Homeboy 241: The paranoid fantasies blooming in his bookie bean. J. Lerner You Got Nothing Coming 234: Spoonyâ€™s little shaved bean is bobbing up and down in fear. J. Hannaham Didnâ€™t Nobody Give a Shit 19: A white man with a baldy bean.

5. (US black/drugs) a drug or tablet.

(a) a package of a drug.

Chicago Trib. 11 Oct. 14/3: A package of drug wrapped in paper is called a â€˜deck,â€™ a â€˜check,â€™ or a â€˜bundle.â€™ If it is in a capsule it is called a â€˜berry,â€™ a â€˜bean,â€™ or a â€˜capâ€™ [DA].

(b) usu. in pl.; any form of tablet, esp. Benzedrine; thus beaned up, under the influence of Benzedrine [resemblance].

Maurer & Vogel Narcotics and Narcotic Addiction (3rd edn). (con. 1960s) D. Goines Whoreson 213: I ran down the pill man and bought his supply of beans. H. Feldman et al. Angel Dust 164: â€˜Beansâ€™ or â€˜downersâ€™. E. Folb Runninâ€™ Down Some Lines 169: Benzedrine â€“ variously called [...] bean, chalk, or wake-up. Totally True Diaries of an Eighties Roller Queen ğŸŒ 22 Sept. Today I went to Traceyâ€™s house. Her brother Bill was there and he had a whole bag of beans [a type of caffeine pill]. I had five an drank them down with two glasses of barrel wash. E. Little Another Day in Paradise 82: Make the call. Get fifty thousand beans. ONDCP Street Terms 2: Bean â€” A capsule containing drugs. W. Keyser â€˜Carny Lingoâ€™ in http://goodmagic.com ğŸŒ Beans, or Beanies â€” Amphetamines (â€˜stay awake for daysâ€™ pills).

6. (US) a Mexican, any Spanish-American; occas. as adj. [stereotyping of the Mexican diet].

Monteleone Criminal Sl. (rev. edn). F. Salas Tattoo the Wicked Cross (1981) 52: Are you the little guy who got cornered by the beans from Santa Clara about a year ago and fought so hard losing they gave you a free pass? G. Swarthout Skeletons 11: You bean bastard. E. Folb Runninâ€™ Down Some Lines 55: Most of the pejoratives characterized Chicanos in terms of the foods associated with them [...] bean, beaner, bean choker. C. Hiaasen Lucky You 228: It was a human bean [...] A nigger is what it looked like.

7. (US black, also big bean) the sun [note comment at beam n.2 ].

D. Burley Orig. Hbk of Harlem Jive 21: With the bean beaming on thy crown. Mezzrow & Wolfe Really the Blues 219: I ainâ€™t greased since the big bean collared a nod in the early black. Wentworth & Flexner DAS.

8. (US) a minuscule or insignificant amount, nothing; cit. 1954 is used in negative, i.e. something.

â€˜Josphine Teyâ€™ Brat Farrar 37: â€˜They owe you something, donâ€™t they?â€™ â€˜No they donâ€™t. Not a beanâ€™. â€˜Curt Cannonâ€™ â€˜Die Hardâ€™ I Like â€™Em Tough (1958) 20: One junkie more or less doesnâ€™t mean beans to a pusher. E. Hunter â€˜. . . Or Leave It Aloneâ€™ in Jungle Kids (1967) 62: There was one cat in the world who meant beans to Joey Angeli â€“ and that was Joey Angeli. L. Davidson Rose of Tibet 189: It did not seem to matter a bean, now that the cat was out of the bag, whether Houston saw the other Europeans or not.

In compounds

beanbag (n.)

(US) the scrotum.

T. Robinson Hard Bounce [ebook] Simultaneously, a tiny heel collided with my hairy beanbag.

bean flicker (n.) [sense 2c above]

a lesbian.

Rogerâ€™s Profanisaurus in Viz 87 Dec. n.p.: bean flicker n. Lesbian. OnLine Dict. of Playground Sl. ğŸŒ bean flicker n. lesbian f. reference to masturbation of a female by stimulation of clitoris.

bean man (n.) [sense 4b above]

(drugs) a seller of any type of drugs in pill form.

(con. 1960s) D. Goines Whoreson 225: I saw the bean man walking down the street.

beanraker (n.) [rake (it) in v.]

(Aus.) one who is good at amassing money.

Bulletin (Sydney) 2 July 15/2: As a bean-raker Dowie could give Booth points.

bean ranch (n.)

(US und.) San Quentin prison, California.

â€˜The Jargon of Thievesâ€™ in Derry Jrnl 8 Sept. 6/5: If [...] a safe robber had been sent to San Quentin [the thief] would say â€˜A gopher-cracker has gone over to the bean ranchâ€™ .

bean slot (n.)

(US prison) a slot in a cell door through food is passed.

J. Hannaham Didnâ€™t Nobody Give a Shit 17: Carlotta pushed her paws through the bean slot and let the COs cuff her.

In phrases

flick the bean (v.) [sense 2c above]

of a woman, to masturbate.

K. Sampson Outlaws (ms.) 129: The scenes with her flicking her bean are fucking good, by the way.

flip oneâ€™s bean (v.) (also flip oneâ€™s beanie) [SE flip/ flip v.4 (2)]

(US) to go crazy, to lose emotional control.

â€˜Weldon Hillâ€˜ Casualties 164: Have you flipped your beanie, Clay? Six watermelons! J. Neugeboren Big Man 92: Next thing I know heâ€™s flipped his bean, dancing around me [...] throwing jabs .

for beans (adv.) [sense 1 above]

(orig. US) in no way whatsoever.

â€˜Dating Adviceâ€™ Column at DatingFun.com ğŸŒ I canâ€™t tell if someone likes me or not for beans.

half-a-bean (n.) (also half-bean)

a half-sovereign, a half-dollar.

Vaux Vocab. of the Flash Lang. Egan Groseâ€™s Classical Dict. of the Vulgar Tongue. Hotten Dict. of Modern Sl. etc. Hotten Sl. Dict. Crowe Aus. Sl. Dict. 34: Half a Bean, half a sovereign. Argus (Melbourne) 20 Sept. 6/4: The half sovereign masquerades as half a bean or half a couter. Exeter & Plymouth Gaz. 4 Feb. 5/6: Ten shillings is known in some circles as a â€˜half-beanâ€™ and a â€˜smeltâ€™. N.-Y. American 26 Apr. in Fleming Unforgettable Season (1981) 54: Four bits (a slang expression signifying half a bean). Smithâ€™s Wkly (Sydney) 7 June 9/6: Slang of Money [...] 10/- is a â€˜half bean,â€™ a â€˜smeltâ€™. P. Di Donato Christ in Concrete 206: â€˜All right, cockos,â€™ commanded Fausta, â€˜throw up half a bean each.â€™.

loose in the bean (adj.) (also loose in the attic, â€¦canoodle, â€¦head, â€¦tiles) [SE loose + attic n. (1)SE head/ ? noodle n.1 (1)/SE tiles]

(US) eccentric, crazy.

Spokane Press (WA) 17 Aug. 4/3: Heâ€™s so loose in his attic that he rattles. C. Mackenzie Sinister Street I 164: We are a couple of barmy chaps, hush not a word! / A little bit loose in our tiles, perhaps, hush, not a word! / Weâ€™re lunatics, lunatics, everybody declares / Weâ€™re a couple of fellows gone wrong in our bellows, / As mad as a pair of March hares. New Scimitar (Memphis, TN) 31 July 10/2: Golfing [...] Those who followed it for a pastime were comical in the conc â€” which is English for loose in the attic. M. Meredith â€˜The Human Head in Sl.â€™ in AS III:5 409: Other expressions which one sometimes hears or sees in popular speech [...] â€˜loose in the beanâ€™. T. Wolfe Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test (1969) 194: Acid rappers, freaks who made a competition out of who could take the most acid â€” they all seemed to end up loose in the head. E. Thompson Garden of Sand (1981) 35: But suggesting something like that with a straight face, he had to be loose in the canoodle. W. Diehl Sharkyâ€™s Machine 272: Iâ€™m not saying heâ€™s a goddamn loony bird. Heâ€™s just, uh . . . a little loose in the attic. T. Szasz Lexicon of Lunacy 57: Loony-tick Loony-tunes Loopy Loose in the bean Loose in the hilts [etc.].

lose oneâ€™s bean (v.) (also lose oneâ€™s bap)

1. to lose oneâ€™s temper.

(con. 1910s) J.T. Farrell Young Lonigan in Studs Lonigan (1936) 63: He finally lost his bean, and dribbled head on into her. J. Morrow Confessions of Proinsias Oâ€™Toole 96: Heâ€™d lost his bap completely [...] he stood shaking a trembling fist under my nostril.

2. (US) to become obsessed with.

H. de Leeuw Underworld Story 120: Dasher Abbandado, a Murder, Inc. hood, lost his bean to a tall, lissome, auburn-haired, devastating cutie, named Connie Malone.

not a bean (n.)

nothing at all, esp. of money.

Bulletin (Sydney) 14 Dec. Red Page/3: If a man is assaulted by highwaymen and robbed he is â€˜stuck up,â€™ and if he has no money whatever it is common to say he â€˜has not a bean.â€™. A. Binstead Pitcher in Paradise 217: The exquisite Smith [...] replied, somewhat dejectedly, â€˜Not a bean.â€™. W.N. Famous Colonel Crook Stories 94: So the bill began to climb like a hod-carrier, and Iâ€™m there with not a bean. â€˜Sax Rohmerâ€™ Golden Scorpion 231: Anâ€™ not a â€˜oatâ€™ in me pocketâ€” not a â€˜beanâ€™! Broke to the wide. I. Rathbone We that Were Young 130: And now Iâ€™ve gone and hitched myself to someone who hasnâ€™t got a beanâ€”not a bean in the worldâ€”apart from his pay! K. Tennant Joyful Condemned 7: â€˜Got any money?â€™ â€˜Not a bean.â€™. â€˜Whisper All Aussie Dict.â€™ in Kings Cross Whisper (Sydney) xxxiii 4/4: cracker: [...] Also â€˜to not have a crackerâ€™. No money. Also not a bean. N. Smith Gumshoe (1998) 175: â€˜So youâ€™ve no money on you, then?â€™ â€˜Not a bean,â€™ I said. K. Sampson Powder 42: I intend to repay nothing for a year. Not a bean. Salvesen & Cousineau Artistsâ€™ Estates: Reputations in Trust 180: We were left with the studio building, my parentsâ€™ house in the Catskills, the paintings, and not a bean to do anything with!

off oneâ€™s bean (adj.)

insane, eccentric.

Lit. Digest 33 738/2: Dan O'Leary said Izzy would go off his bean. R. Beach Heart of the Sunset 268: Heâ€™s queer â€” heâ€™s off his bean. F. Greene ZR Wins 160: But heâ€™s just a little bit off his bean, the poor thing. J.T. Farrell Gas-House McGinty 349: Iâ€™ll bet as sure as Christ made green apples that heâ€™ll go off his bean. K. Wilford â€˜Maggieâ€™ at Vanagon.com ğŸŒ â€˜This guy is really off his bean,â€™ I thought. â€˜He really thinks this box on wheels is a person.â€™.

use oneâ€™s bean (v.)

to think, to act intelligently, to work things out.

C.T. Clark diary 24 June in Soldier Letters (1919) 26: The wounded, waiting to be taken away, were in a horrible state of fright, and couldnâ€™t use their beans at all. J.E. Lighter Word Improvisation in Atlantic Monthly Mar. ğŸŒ Interest in the contents of politiciansâ€™ noggins (long ago the word referred to a kind of drinking mug) is hardly new; the electorate has always liked candidates who use the old bean without being too obvious about it.

Uses based on SE/sense 5 above, pertaining to Mexicans or Hispanics

In derivatives

beanmobile (n.) [SE/sense 5 above + -mobile sfx]

(US) a â€˜lowriderâ€™ automobile, as customized and driven by Mexican/Puerto Rican teenagers and gang members.

J. Ellroy Brownâ€™s Requiem 16: I ditched the bean-mobile at the Ford lot. S. Morgan Homeboy 58: Joe thought [...] heâ€™d been electrocuted by his highvoltage beanmobile.

In compounds

beanbag (n.)

(US) a Mexican.

P. Barnes Pawns 63: He is called â€˜shithead,â€™ â€˜turd,â€™ â€˜maggot,â€™ [...] or â€˜beanbagâ€™ (an epithet for chicano) depending on the DIâ€™s vocabulary and the recruitâ€™s physical or racial characteristics.

bean bandit (n.)

(US) a Mexican.

J. Brosnan Long Season (1975) 230: â€˜Come on, Orlando, you bean bandit,â€™ I yelled at the TV screen. [Ibid.] 269: Bean Bandit A Latin American ballplayer. Current Sl. IV:3-4 (1970). E. Bunker Little Boy Blue (1995) 145: Where youâ€™re going thereâ€™s lots of toughies â€“ Okies, niggers and bean bandits.

bean choker (n.)

(US) a Spanish-American.

E. Folb Runninâ€™ Down Some Lines 55: Most of the pejoratives characterized Chicanos in terms of the foods associated with them [...] bean choker.

beantown (n.)

1. (US) that part of a town in which the poor or the immigrants live; such immigrants are stereotypically, but not invariably, Hispanics.

J. Green Words Apart 154: Beantown returns to a Mexican inference in a parallel meaning: the poorest, immigrant section of a town or city.

2. see also Bean Town

SE in slang uses

[see also compounds and phrases under beans n.3 ]

In compounds

beanbelly (n.)

see separate entries.

beanbrain (n.) [the implication is of minimal size]

(US) a fool; thus beanbrained adj., foolish.

S. Bellow Augie March (1996) 48: Youâ€™ll see how beanbrained she is. â€˜Whisper All Aussie Dict.â€™ in Kings Cross Whisper (Sydney) xxxii 6/1: bean brain: Stupid oaf. R. Woodley Bears 90: Come on, bean-brain [HDAS]. R. Aven-Bray Ridgey-Didge Oz Jack Lang 21: Bean Brain Fool. Traywick Gallery (Berkeley CA) catalogue at www.paulsonpress.com ğŸŒ And in Black Rabbit, the black shape of a crouching bunny rests above off-color insults printed pretty in pink: Slimeball, Lumpkhead [sic], Stinker, Beanbrain. CyberSoccerNews ğŸŒ You cannot go to Asia, broadcast the worldâ€™s greatest and most important sporting event to an audience of untold millions, and sound like a subliterate beanbrain.

bean-count (v.) [? erect nipples]

(US campus) to stare at breasts.

Online Sl. Dict. ğŸŒ bean count v 1. to stare at breasts, usually in cold weather. (â€˜We just sat on the porch bean counting.â€™).

bean counter (n.)

(orig. US) anyone who deals with financial matters, esp. an accountant or statistician; thus bean-counting n. and adj.

Interfaces Feb. 74: [title] The measure of M.S./O.R. applications; or, Letâ€™s hear it for the bean counters [OED]. Indep. 29 Nov. 17/1: The highly respected beancounters at Price Waterhouse have failed to recognise that times are changing in the City. R. Marcinko Rogue Warrior (1993) 380: A no-load, bean-counting pain-in-the-ass. Bug (Aus.) 28 July ğŸŒ Cut across to those genius bean-counters at Norths who have got a $20 million piece of Central Coast real estate. Sydney Morning Herald 11 July 40: Who they [i.e UK cricketers] are individually, and what their talents might be collectively, seem to be factors of complete irrelevance to the boofheads and bean counters who run the game. http://grey-magazine.com July ğŸŒ Sometimes I just feel like a bureaucratâ€”a yellowing, servile bean-counter. Betoota-isms 62: Bean Counter [...] 1. A tax accountant 2. A white collar professional who records, tallies and analyses financial numbers 3. A corporate drone devoid of personality, often in training for a triathlon or long-distance fun run. A. Kirzman Giuliani 182: â€˜I wasnâ€™t a politician,â€™ Kerik said. â€˜I wasnâ€™t one of these fucking bean countersâ€™. M. Herron Secret Hours 299: â€˜You know who the Park usually sends on these bean-counting missions?â€™.

bean-eater (n.) [the supposed preference of Bostonians for beans (cf. Bean Town )]

1. (US) an inhabitant of Boston, Massachusetts; thus bean-eating adj., Bostonian in manner.

C. Mathews Career of Puffer Hopkins 19: A select circle of acquaintance, among wharfingers, small boatmen and bean-eaters, near the market. G.E. Clark Seven Years of a Sailorâ€™s Life 252: Take that, you bean-eater. Eve. Teleg. (Philadelphia, PA) 26 Mar. 5/1: The Bostonian did not object to being called a bean-eater. L.A. Dly Herald 21 Aug. 1/5: The fight to a finish between [...] Daniel Kelliher of Boston, and Joe Ellingsworth of New York [...] Ellingsworth received another in the stomach and the bean-eater barely parried a blow at his face. The New Yorker got a slashing blow on the side of the head, and the bean-eater paid for it with a light blow on the lip. letter in Marble Hill Press (MO) 16 Jan. 1/2: [signed] An Old-Time Bean-Eater. Golden Caribbean 86: Then there are the clerks, book-keepers, and managers of the commissary [...] young fellows from the Southern part of the United States mostly, now and then a bean-eater from Boston. J. Ware Passing Eng. of the Victorian Era 22/2: Bean-eater (New York). A term of scorn for a citizen of Boston, referring to the former Sunday custom observed by some Bostonians of accepting for dinner on that day cold belly of pork and colder beans. Century Illus. Mthly Mag. 80 109/2: Why, you fool Yankee bean-eater, there ainâ€™t neither of us knows a bloominâ€™ bit about the engines of this ship. Munseyâ€™s Mag. 73 292/2: Luke had a Boston stock-plunger coming to his clairvoyant shop in search of advance information about a certain stock. The spirits were urging the bean-eater to buy this stock and hold it for a rise. Wood & Goddard Dict. Amer. Sl. Amer. Motorist 21-2 17: â€˜A motorist,â€™ says the daily Boston Globe in blowing off steam, â€˜is a citizen who thinks heâ€™s obeying the law when he slows down as he passes the stop sign.â€™ Evidently the erudite bean eater hasn't known many AAA drivers. Wentworth & Flexner DAS. Maledicta VII 24: Groups as disparate as Mexicans and Yankees, especially Bostonians, have been called bean eater. H. Rawson Dict. of Invective (1991) 228: Bean eater, which also is a resident of Boston, a.k.a. Beantown.

2. see also bean-eater

beanfeast (n.) (also bean feed) [SE beanfeast, an annual dinner given by employers to their workers; in its original form beans were a featured dish]
